quote: Rom, I have delightful news.  It's    finally arrived.
It has?
And I guarantee we're the only    establishment in this sector to offer    the entire cycle.
We are?  Why that's marvelous, isn't    it, Morn?  Really... amazing.    (stares blankly at     PADD)   What cycle?
Idiot, don't you recognize profit    when you see it?  You're looking at    the latest Holosuite programs from    Phalonia Prime.
Yes, when it comes to designing adult    Holosuite programs, the Phalonians    display true genius.       If you don't believe me, take a peek    at the image menu.
Let's see, where to begin.  Ah, here    we go, Scenario Fourteen-C, "A picnic    with the Pleasure Goddess of Rixx."
Now that's what I call a picnic.
I believe Holosuite Six is    available.
That Morn, he always was a sucker    for a Phalonian Holo-program.
What do you think you're doing?
Nothing, brother.
The story of your life.  Now get to    work.
If anyone wants me, I'll be in...       ... Holosuite Three.
Quark!
Not now, Odo.
We have to talk.
It'll have to wait.
It can't wait.
Of course not.  Well make it fast.     I have... business to attend to.
You remember that Subytt freighter    we were discussing the other day?     The one you claimed was smuggling    defective isolinear rods to Bajor?
Yes, yes, what about it?
Well, I conducted a little    investigation of that freighter, and    do you know what I discovered?
That I was telling the truth?
That's right.  I arrested the first    officer and two of the crew.
Congratulations, Constable, I knew    you could do it.  Now if you don't    mind I'm needed upstairs.
Hold on, I'm not finished with you.
Really, Odo, sometimes I think there's    no pleasing you.  I help you crack a    notorious smuggling ring, yet you    still insist on treating me like an    enemy.
You are my enemy.
Then how do you explain my helping    you?
That's just it, I can't explain it.
It's simple, really.  I figured we'd    been at each others' throats long    enough.  It's time we called a truce.
A truce?  You must be joking.
Ask that Subytt First Officer if I'm    joking.  From now on, you and I are    going to be friends.
You're up to something.
Now why would you say that?
Because you're always up to something.
I can see it's going to take time,    but eventually you'll learn to trust    me.
That'll be the day.
(very pleased with     himself)   I don't think I can remember Odo    looking quite so perplexed.
He's not alone.  Those Subytt    smugglers were a potential source of    great profit.
Must I quote you the seventy-sixth    Rule of Acquisition?
The seventy-sixth rule...
"Every once in a while, declare    peace."       It confuses the hell out of your    enemies.
Hey Quark, how are your lobes?
Tingling at the sight of you.
What will it be?  Another black hole?
Don't have the time.  Ship's about    to pull out.  You know of anyone    headed to Bajor?
Ships go back and forth from there    all the time.  Why?
I promised someone I'd deliver this    for them.  But it looks like I'm not    going to make it there this trip.
It's an earring.
I know it's an earring.  It was given    to me by a maintenance worker on    Cardassia Four.
Are you saying a Cardassian gave you    a Bajoran earring?
He asked me to take it to Bajor.     Said whoever I showed it to would    understand.
He said that?
Well, this is a Bajoran station,    right?  There must be someone here    who'll know what to do with it.
Oh, there is.
Who?
Me.
Come in.
Surprise.
What do you want?
I always wondered what your quarters    looked like.
That better not be your only reason    for being here.
You don't entertain much, do you?
I entertain a lot.  I just don't    entertain you.
Let me guess, the bedroom.
You take one step in here and I    promise it'll be your last.
It could be worth it.
You have five seconds to tell me    what you want.
Aren't you going to offer me a    beverage?
Five... four...
Can we at least sit down?
...three... two... one.
Wait.
I brought you something...
Where did you get this?
Is it valuable?
I said, where did you get it?
From a Boslic Freighter Captain.     She got it from a Cardassian.
Where?
On Cardassia Four.  That's what she    told me anyway.       Consider it a gift.
Hey, Dad, wait up.
You got a minute?
Sure.  What's up?
I've got great news.
You passed your algebra test?
Better than that.
You figured out how to hit Sandy    Koufax's curve ball.
No, even better.
Better than hitting Koufax's curve?     This I want to hear.
You remember that Bajoran girl I    told you about?
The one with the great smile?
That's right, Laira.  I decided to    ask her out.
Good for you.  And now you've come    to the old man for advice on what to    say to her.
Dad...
The main thing is you can't be afraid    of rejection...
Dad, I already asked her out.  And    she said yes.
She did, well that's wonderful.
I was just wondering if you had any    ideas what we could do.  I was kinda    thinking of taking her to the    Holosuites.
The Holosuites?  I don't think so.
Why not?
Because you're too young to take a    girl to the Holosuites.
Okay, then how about if I bring her    to our quarters?
No, no quarters.
We're just going to talk.
You can talk in public.
It's not the same.
You want to talk?    (pointing to the     Promenade's second     level)   Take her upstairs.  That way you can    talk and watch the ships go through    the wormhole.
That's boring.
Since when?
Since I started going out with girls.
This is your first date.
Yeah, and I don't want it to be my    last.
Commander, I need to speak with you.
One moment, Major...
Dad, I can see you're not ready to    have this conversation.
I'm not ready.
I'll just have to come up with some    ideas on my own.  Really, don't worry    about it.
(trying to convince     himself)   Who's worried?
(interrupting his     reverie)   Commander...
Join me, Major.
One Raktajino with a jacarine peel.
Nothing for me.
One icoberry torte.
So, what can I do for you, Major?
I need to borrow a runabout.
What for?
You really don't want to ask me that.
It's too late.  I already have.
Then you don't want to know the    answer.
Major, I can't loan you a Starfleet    runabout without knowing where you    plan on taking it.
(fixing Sisko with     her best level stare)   To Cardassia Four to rescue a Bajoran    prisoner of war.
You're right.  I wish you hadn't    told me.
This earring was recently smuggled    off the planet.    (points to part of     the design)   See this?  It's the insignia of Li    Nalas.
The resistance leader?
The greatest we ever had.  His victory    over Gul Zarale in hand-to-hand    combat...
I've heard the story, Major.  But    wasn't he reported killed in action?

The body was never found.       Look Commander, I wouldn't be asking    this if I thought there was another    way to rescue Li.  But Bajoran ships    don't have the maneuverability or    defensive capabilities to get me    safely in and out of Cardassian    territory.
You're sure this is genuine?
Dax found dermal residue on the    backing.  A genetic analysis matched    it to Li's DNA records.       It's genuine all right.
Have you told the provisional    government?
I contacted three ministers.  Their    responses were exactly what I    expected.
In other words, they're unwilling to    risk a war with Cardassia over an    earring.       I can't say I blame them.

Commander, we both know the    provisional government is made up of    political opportunists too busy    fighting among themselves to care    what happens to Bajor.       And since the loss of the Kai, the    situation has only gone from bad to    worse.  There are reports of factional    fighting in half a dozen districts...    religious riots have spread throughout    the southern islands... Bajor needs    a leader.  Someone the people will    listen to.  Someone they can trust.
And you think Li Nalas is that leader?
I know he is.
O'Brien to Sisko.
Go ahead, Chief.
I think you and Odo had better join    me in the Habitat Ring.  Level    Thirteen, Section Four.  There's    something you should see.
We'll be right there.
So, do I get the runabout?
I'll have to think it over.
I was on my way to Crossover Bridge    Three to do some repair work on the    field modulators.  I noticed this.
It's the emblem of the Alliance for    Global Unity.  They call themselves    "The Circle."
"The Circle," huh.  Well, what gives    them the right to go mucking up our    station?
They're an extremist faction who    believe in Bajor for Bajorans.  All    other species are inferior and should    be expelled from the planet.
I understand this emblem has been    appearing all over Bajor.
That's correct.  But this is the    first time I've seen it here.
I want to be informed immediately if    it shows up anyplace else on the    station.
Understood.
If they think scrawling a couple of    signs is going to send us packing,    they've got another thing coming.
Right now they're just letting us    know we're vulnerable.
I wouldn't be overly concerned,    Commander.  This section is a low    security area.
As of now, Constable, there are no    "low security areas" on this station.
You wanted to see me, Benjamin?
Have a seat.
Am I to assume this conversation is    going to be about baseball?
Not this time.
Good.
I thought you enjoyed talking about    baseball.
Curzon enjoyed it.  But not half as    much as he led you to believe.
So what's on your mind, Benjamin.
I've been thinking about our mission    here.  I look at the turmoil on Bajor    and I see everything we fought for    this past year starting to unravel.
I told you when we came here this    was going to be a tough assignment.     Of course, I didn't know it was going    to be this tough...
What if I told you I knew someone    who could bring stability to Bajor.     Someone who could unite the factions    and give us a chance to do our job.
I'd say give Kira the runabout.
How do you know about Kira wanting a    runabout?
She told me.
I thought this was supposed to be a    covert mission.
I promise not to tell.
All right, supposing I do help, and    she does rescue Li Nalas.  What do    we say to the Cardassians?
The question is, what do they say to    us?  They swore they released all    their Bajoran prisoners.
Dax...
Yes?
You're sure Curzon didn't love    baseball.
Positive.
Chief, Major Kira needs a runabout...
Then she will be going to Cardassia    Four, after all.
How do you know about Cardassia Four?
She told me all about it.
Is there anyone on this station she    didn't tell?
I doubt she mentioned it to Quark.
Well then, as far as Quark's    concerned, she's going to Lamenda    Prime to bring back mineral samples.
Very good, sir.
Now, is there any way we can prevent    the Cardassian sensors from picking    up the runabout's signature?

I could modulate the engine's power    emissions, reconfigure the deflector    shield grid, and install field buffers    around the subspace emitter coil.     By the time I'm done, the Cardies    will think they're reading a Lissepian    transport.
I see you've already given this a    bit of thought.
I suppose I have at that.
Come in.
Commander... Chief... I was just    getting ready to leave.
I just stopped by to wish you luck.       And to let you know that Chief O'Brien    will be accompanying you on your    mission.
I don't think that's a good idea.     Having a Federation officer along    could cause complications for you    later.
I'm willing to risk that.       You're an excellent pilot, Major...    but O'Brien here is better.       And I want to make sure I get my    runabout back in one piece.
I appreciate the offer.  But this is    a Bajoran problem.
I don't agree.  The truth is I need    Li Nalas back on Bajor as much as    you do.
Besides, I've seen how Cardassians    treat their prisoners.  No one should    have to suffer like that.
If the Cardassians get their hands    on us, we'll be the ones suffering.
They'll have to catch us first.
I suppose I could use the company.
You have the controls, Chief.
Right.
Before we go, there's just one thing    we need to clear up between us.
And what would that be?
This mission can end only one of two    ways.  Either we bring back Li    Nalas... or we don't come back at    all.
Understood.
Then take us out of here, Mister    O'Brien.
Initializing launch sequence.
How long until we reach Cardassia    Four?
I'd estimate another thirty minutes.
Hold on... We're being scanned.
Can you get a fix on the source?
It's position is holding steady at    bearing two-one-nine mark two-three.
It must be a navigational control    post.  It's probably just a routine    scan.
We're being hailed.
On the other hand we could be in    serious trouble.
They're repeating the hail.
We're on the edge of their scanner    range.  That puts us out of visual    contact.  I say we try and bluff    'em.
This is Cardassian Navigational    Control Post Twenty-Four.  Identify    yourself.
This is the Lissepian transport    Martuk.
According to our scan your subspace    field emitters appear to be    malfunctioning.
The field buffers must be distorting    our power signature.
We've been having trouble with our    phase modulators.  We're attempting    to correct the problem.
Do you require assistance?  We can    dispatch a repair ship.
Bloody hell.  They want to help us.
Your offer is most appreciated, Post    Twenty-Four.  But unnecessary.
Are you certain?  Your power signature    is still fluctuating.
He's getting suspicious.

I believe we can correct the problem    on our own.  Besides, Gul Marayn is    waiting on Cardassia Four to receive    my shipment of Rulot seeds.  Any    delay could ruin the entire crop...    and the Gul's mood.
Understood.  You can put in for    repairs after you deliver your cargo.
My plan exactly.       They've broken off their transmission.
Tell me, Major, who's this Gul Marayn.
Don't ask me.  I just made him up.
We're in synchronous orbit above the    Hutet Labor camp.
I've limited the bio-scan to detect    only Bajoran lifeforms.
Hold on.  I'm getting multiple    readings.  There must be about a    dozen Bajoran prisoners down there.
Is there any way to beam up more    than two at a time?
I'm afraid not.  And as soon as we    beam up the first two all hell's    gonna break loose in that camp.
And there's no guarantee that Li    will be one of the first two.       What's security like down there?
The compound's surrounded by a    standard Cardassian forcefield.
We'll have to land.  It's our only    chance of getting them all out of    there.
I'll find us a secluded spot to put    down.
How do I look?
I doubt there's a Cardassian alive    who could resist you.
I hope you're right.
So do I.
What's all this?
I'm not quite sure.
Halt.
We're here to see the prefect.
What for?
She has an appointment with him.
I used to be stationed on Bajor.
Then you know why the prefect doesn't    want to be kept waiting.
What would it cost me for an    appointment.
More than you can afford.
Two strips of gold-pressed latinum and    she's all yours.
He wouldn't know what to do with me.
She needs disciplining.
From a boy like you?  I don't think    you're capable of it.
Step back.  I want to examine what    I'm paying for.
Of course.  But no sampling the    merchandise until the sale is    completed.
Come here.
Now, show me why you're worth two    strips of gold press latinum.
All right.
Li Nalas?
Who are you?
Major Kira Nerys.  We've come to get    you out of here.
The earring... you got it.
Yes.
I don't understand.  My earring was    lost...
No, I had it smuggled back to Bajor.
Gentlemen, I suggest you save this    discussion for later.
Come on.  We have a ship waiting.
We'll never make it at this rate.
Get Li to Bajor.    (pointing to three     other prisoners)   We'll stay behind... hold them off    until you reach your ship.
No.  I won't allow it.
Don't you see, we did this for you.       Get him back safely.  That's all    that matters.
You have my word.
Then go.
Ready to launch, Major.
Not yet.  Some of the others still    might make it.
Standing by.
I'm picking up two Galor class     warships entering orbit.  They    should be overhead in one minute,    forty-five seconds.
Major, you can't leave those men    behind.
One minute, thirty seconds.  If we    don't leave now, Major, we never    will.
Take us home, Chief.
Yes, sir.
Careful, watch your step.
Easy now, I have you.
He took a phaser hit.
Doctor, these people have been    prisoners for ten years.  They need    medical attention...
And they'll get it.  But first we'd    better see to this wound.       Bashir to Dax.
Go ahead, Doctor.
I have a patient here requiring    emergency treatment.  Beam us to the    Infirmary.
Stand by.
Commander, I need to talk to...
Ah, Major Kira, I'm glad you could    join us.
(to Sisko, trying to     cover)   I'm sorry.  I didn't know you were    busy.
Apparently not.
I'll just wait outside.
Hold on, Major.  There's something I    want you to hear.       Go ahead, Dukat.
Major, I just informed Commander    Sisko that the Cardassian High Command    has issued a formal apology to the    people of Bajor.
An apology...

We had no idea that Bajoran prisoners    were still being held on Cardassia    Four.  Such detentions are a direct    violation of supreme directive twenty-   six-forty-five.  I assure you the    camp prefect will be chastised    accordingly.
What about the prisoners who were    left behind?
They're already en route to Bajor.
(one surprise after     another)   Well... I look forward to their safe    return.
I'm sure you do.  I hope our quick    response to this unfortunate situation    will prove once and for all that    Cardassia is no longer your enemy.
Commander... ?
I'm as surprised as you are.
There must be a reason why they're    being so accommodating.
I'm sure there is.  But until we can    figure out their motives, let's just    be grateful that all the prisoners    are being returned safely.
Congratulations on the success of    your mission, Major.
There, that should do it.       How do you feel?
Better.
Luckily your wound wasn't as serious    as it looked.  You've probably had a    lot worse.
Actually this one was bad enough.
You know, I've read all about your    battle with Gul Zarale.
(he's heard it all     before)   That was a long time ago.
Well, I consider myself something of    a history buff and I must say some    of the campaigns you led against the    Cardassians were truly remarkable    examples of tactical...
Doctor, I think you'll find that    others enjoy talking about those    days more than I do.
Of course.
Amazing.
What is?
Being here.       Years ago I worked in one of this    station's ore processing plants.
I think you'll find that things have    changed considerably.
Commander, a transport carrying    Minister Jaro has arrived from Bajor.
Major, I think you should have the    honor of welcoming him aboard.
Thank you, Commander.
If you're hungry, the Replimat has    some passable Bajoran food.
Actually, I'm a bit tired.  I think    I'd like to see my quarters.
Of course.
It appears you've been recognized.
Minister Jaro.
Major...
Where is he?
He's on the Promenade with Commander    Sisko.
And he's all right?
Considering what he's gone through    the last ten years.
(shaking his head in     wonder)   Li Nalas... alive.  Who would have    ever imagined...
The prophets were kind to you today,    Major.
I'd say they were kind to all of us.
You know your little adventure has    made you some enemies in the Chamber    of Ministers.
I'm not surprised.  All I did was    risk my life...
What you did, Major, was declare war    on Cardassia.  Thankfully they    declined the invitation.
I'd do it again if it meant bringing    Li Nalas home.

I'm sure you would.  And though    officially I have to warn you that    the next time you disobey orders    will mean the end of your military    service... as a private citizen... I    want to thank you for what you've    done this day.
That's nice to hear.
Now, take me to see Li Nalas.
Let's move back, please.  No more    pushing.
I'm sorry about this, Commander.
I don't think they're going to leave    until you say a few words.
I agree.
(wishing there was     some other way)   If that's what it takes...
It's good to be free.
It's good to know that Bajor is    free.
Yes, it is good to be free.
It really is you, isn't it.
I'm Li Nalas.
I'm Minister Jaro Essa and it's a    great pleasure to welcome you home.
Believe me, it's a pleasure to be    here.
I hope you won't mind if I address    the crowd.  After all, you can't    expect a politician to pass up an    opportunity like this...
Go right ahead...

Fellow Bajorans, I have only one    thing to say to you today... To ask    of you, really... Never forget this    moment.  Because I promise you that    years from now your children and    your grandchildren will want to know    what it was like the day Li Nalas    returned to Bajor.
I hope you'll find these quarters    satisfactory.
Commander, I just spent ten years in    a Cardassian labor camp.  I'm just    happy to have a moment's privacy.
Enjoy it while you can.  Judging    from the crowd on the Promenade, a    moment is all you're going to get.
I thought they'd have forgotten me    by now.
It appears you were wrong.
This morning I was a slave and tonight    I'm a hero.
It must seem a little overwhelming.

I'll tell you what is overwhelming,    Commander.  It's knowing that    something I've waited for my whole    life has finally happened.       The Cardassians are gone... we've    won.       You've been there recently. What's    it like, a free Bajor?
I think you'll be pleased... for the    most part.
"Most part"?
Bajor lacks strong leadership.
So that's what Major Kira meant.    (off Sisko's     questioning look)   On the runabout, she told me my return    would bring stability to Bajor.
She's right.  Bajor could use your    help.  And frankly so could I.       But before you go off saving Bajor,    I suppose you could use a good night's    sleep.
Sounds like I'm going to need it.
One for you... six for me.  One for    you... six for me.
Would you stop looking so glum.     Payday is supposed to be a time of    joy.
I know, brother.  But every week    it's the same thing.  Six for you    and only one for me.  It's not fair.
You're right.
I am?
Yes, it's not fair.
It's not?
Absolutely not.
One for you, and seven for me.     One for you, and seven for me.  Is    that better?
And where are you going?
To bed.  To dream of an equal share    of profits.
Dream on.       One for you, seven for me.
What is it now?
I'm sorry, but we're closed.  You    fellows on your way to a party?
(patience wearing     thin)   Hold still.
Doctor, will there be a scar?
I said, hold still.
Does that mean yes?
No.  This dermal regenerator should    repair the damaged tissue as well as    prevent any scarring.
Unless, of course, you don't hold    still.
Did you recognize any of your    assailants?
They were wearing masks.
And you're sure they didn't say    anything?
Not a word.  They just came in...       ... branded me and left.
The Promenade is usually deserted at    this hour.  No one saw them enter or    leave.
Constable, I want all security    personnel on full alert.
I've already seen to it.
Who's responsible for this?
An extremist group from Bajor, who    call themselves The Circle.
Bajorans did this?
I'm afraid so.
But why?
Their goal is to rid Bajor of all    non-Bajorans.
Hasn't the provisional government    tried to stop them... ?
Oh, they've tried.  But the truth is    the Circle is more organized than    the government.
Well, the government better get    organized, because I intend to sue    them for financial compensation.
(in no mood for Quark's     antics)   Not now, Quark.
People have grown impatient with the    government's inability to get things    done, so they turn to the Circle.
We need someone to speak out against    these reactionaries.  Someone the    people will listen to.
There, that should do it.
How do I look?
As handsome as ever.
Really.
Jake?  What are you doing up?
I couldn't sleep.
So, how was your date?  It was    tonight, wasn't it?
It was supposed to be.  She couldn't    make it.
It happens.
She said her father wouldn't let her    go out with me.
Why not?
Because I'm not a Bajoran.
That's not much of a reason.       Jake... there are things happening    on Bajor... bad things... I'm sorry    you've become a victim of them.  You    don't deserve it.  Nobody does.
Now it's time for bed, okay?
Night, Dad.
Commander, there's a call for you    from the Tygarian freighter docked    on Upper Pylon Two.
Put it through.

Commander Sisko, I am Romah Doek,    executive officer of the Nanut.  We    were preparing to depart the station    for the Gamma Quadrant when we    discovered a Bajoran citizen trying    to board our ship disguised as a    crew member.
I was hoping you'd know what to do    with him.
The Nanut isn't scheduled to return    from the Gamma Quadrant for two years.
Actually I planned on staying there    considerably longer.
I don't follow.
Commander, I'm going to tell you a    story.  You may even believe it.
I'm listening.

During the occupation I was a member    of a minor resistance cell, the name's    unimportant.  One day, this was in    the mountains surrounding the Sahving    valley, we were ambushed by Cardassian    troops.  Only three of us managed to    escape.  We hid in the hills for two    days, but finally the lack of food    and water forced us down into the    valley.  We made our way to a ridge    above a small lake.  As I was the    only one still carrying a phaser, I    went ahead to scout for the enemy.     Halfway down the embankment I slipped    and went sprawling on my back down    to the edge of the lake just as a    huge Cardassian emerged from the    water.  He must have just finished    bathing.  He stood there frozen in    surprise, dressed only in his    underwear, shivering from the cold.     I lay there looking up at him too    stunned to move.  It was only when    he reached over for a phaser rifle    lying across his clothes on a nearby    rock that I realized I was still    holding my own phaser.  I shot him,    his body collapsed on top of me,    which is how my companions found us    a moment later.

One of them recognized him as Gul    Zarale, responsible for the massacre    of a half-dozen Bajoran villages.  I    tried to tell them what happened,    but they had already convinced    themselves that I killed Zarale during    some kind of savage struggle.       Which is what they insisted on telling    every Bajoran we met.  And no matter    how hard I denied it, the story    continued to spread until it seemed    all of Bajor had heard it.  Soon    every victory won by the resistance    was attributed to my leadership.     Stories of my courage, my brilliance,    my daring grew more and more    unbelievable... yet people insisted    on believing them.  My reputation    even followed me into the labor    camp... my presence alone seemed to    inspire my fellow prisoners... and    all I had done was shot an unarmed    Cardassian in his underwear.  I'll    never forget that look on his face    as he died.  He was so... embarrassed.       Commander, I did what Bajor needed    me to do.  I've allowed myself to be    a slave to my reputation all these    years.  Isn't that enough?
They still need you.
But I'm not the man they think I am.
Perhaps not.       But Bajor doesn't need a man, it    needs a symbol, and that's what    you are.

No one's asking you to lead troops    into battle, or to kill a hundred    Cardassians with your bare hands.       But I saw you in front of that crowd    on the Promenade.  They look at you    and they see strength, and honor,    and decency.
They look at you and they see the    best of themselves.
But it's all based on a lie.
No.  It's based on a legend.  And    legends are as powerful as any truth.     Bajor still needs that legend.       It needs you.
The Yelikan transport is prepared    for departure.
